title: Oldham coupler for TEVO Tarantula
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Oldham coupler for TEVO Tarantula

Here's a remix of Doron Shalev's brilliant oldham coupler for the TEVO Tarantula. This device will help people get rid of the Z-wobbles. This is a part of my complete remake of Tevo's printer.

The manual is available in the "Thing Files" section.

Tarantula complete remake - Links :
  • Brackets for single/dual Z : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039503
  • Modular Vertical X-carriage available here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2034743
  • Belt tensioner for Y axis : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039510
  • Doron's oldham coupler available here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039498

Special thanks to :
Rob Cad (Thingirob) : http://www.thingiverse.com/thingirob/designs
Sergiy Matsak (MSA) : http://www.thingiverse.com/_MSA_/designs
Bruce Walker (bdwalker1) : http://www.thingiverse.com/bdwalker1/designs
Doron Shalev

comments.author: flannelhead

comments.text:
You could have made it simpler and even better by doing as I did on my Geetech Al. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830451
The X gantry must hang from the leadscrews/top bearing, and NO bearing at the bottom. Therefore the leadscrews will only exerts an up force on the gantry. By attaching the top and bottom of the leadscrew unless the leadscrews and Z rail are perfectly // (good luck to achieve that with this kind of machine) the leadscrews will exert a radial force that is in the X-Y plane.
Even if the leadscrews are bent, the radial force will be far less and should be contained by the Z rails.
A simple application of isostatism
comments.author: MKSA

author: Elzariant

description.text: Use these parts to securely attach your Logitech webcam on any device.

1) Print both parts
2) Plug in the camera (remove it from its original support)
3) Close its cage with M4 threaded rods
4) Enjoy ! This part was originally created as a camera holder for our 2011 robot participating in the eurobot cup.

Headband fits on the Makerbot Replicator2 bed.  
Word of caution - doesn't completely work as an adult headband.   Also, the corners are sharp - so suggest gluing some padding on the end before wearing.  
I will be trying a multi-part modification that will have both a working headband, and snap-in spikes that are more proportional to the actual statue of liberty crown.

2017/12/06 : Corrected Rear bottom bracket
2017/10/11 : Added new Top Brackets (v2.1). These new brackets avoid any loss of Z-height on prints (gain of 20mm).

comments.author: TwistedStick

description.text:
This is a parametric version of the distal phalange used for Robohand.  Really, it is a combination of the intermediate and the distal phalanges in one part.  
I tried to make a Robohand scaled to adult size, and found a couple of areas I thought could be improved. First, I did not like that all of the fingers were equal in length - very unlike a normal hand. Second, the uniform length was too short - smaller than a pinky finger. Third, there was no ability to control the hole sizes, leading to some problems with holes that were too big or too small. Fourth, there was no ability to control the fit between parts, leading to too much lateral motion in some joints.  
This version allows you to tweak the settings to make the fingers custom to your needs. It allows you to set the scale factor to match the other Robohand parts. You can then set the length of the intermediate portion of the phalange, the size of the holes for the knuckles, the size of the hole for the bungies, the size of the hole for the drive string, and the width of the slot that the proximal phalange fits into.  
The ability to set the hole size for the knuckle on this part is pretty useful.  You need to tap threads into that hole.  As it scaled larger, I found there was not a lot of plastic to hold the tap.  
This version currently only lets you set the length of the intermediate phalange.  The actual distal portion is always the same.  I thought of changing this, but decided it was diminishing returns.  Most people do not have a lot of difference in distal lengths.  If you set the intermediate lengths with this part, and then use my proximal phalange (thing 203208) to set that length, the finger lengths will be very natural looking - without worrying about the distal length.  
This is a pretty hard part to print.  My version is neither easier, nor harder to print than the original Robohand version.  I can get them to print acceptably at this point.  Let me know if you want to know my Slic3r settings.  Keep in mind that the distal portion (which is the part that gets a little rough when printing) gets wrapped with string and dipped in rubber.  That will cover minor print defects.  
I have made a first test print of these - scaled to the actual finger lengths of the person for whom I am making the hand. They appear to work properly, but the hand is not complete and more testing is needed. For that reason, I am going to call this a work in progress for now.  
NOTE: I have no medical training whatsoever, and make no warrantee of any sort regarding this part. I am providing it in the hopes that it will be helpful for others. If, however, you intend to use it, seek appropriate medical attention from a trained physician.

Open the .scad file and customize values in the PARAMETERS section.  
Start by setting the scale factor to match the scaling used for any other Robohand parts. The sample .stl files I included used a 1.3 scale. Once the scale is set, set the length of the intermediate phalange. If desired, adjust the hole sizes (in mm) for different size screws, different size bungie cords, or different size strings. If desired, adjust the width of the slot that accepts the proximal phalange for a looser or tighter fit.  
Once the values are set, use OpenScad to compile the object. Be forewarned that this takes a long time to compile. I do it on a laptop that is a few years old, and it takes about 2 hours per finger. Although that is a long time, I think it is worth it to have customized parts. It should be less time on a newer, more powerful system. You need a fairly recent version of OpenScad because of the dependence of this object on the Minkowski function that had bugs in some older versions. Once the file compiles, export it as an stl. You will probably need to use Netfabb to repair the stl. Then slice and print the repaired stl.

G Teng T909 MOD

includes SMA-Connector, RX5808 OSD (Channel Autosearch, Raceband, etc), Mini DVR, 600 mAH Lipo.

https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2668967-GTeng-T909-FPV-Watch-OSD-Raceband-Modding

  • TBD-
    Mostly https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showpost.php?p=36447333&postcount=65

comments.text: You could consider consolidating the how to for this - your picture at https://static.rcgroups.net/forums/attachments/5/0/3/7/2/6/a9686619-34-20170114_170529.jpg is very important to show where the vin/vout of the dvr goes. In short the vin of the dvr is coming from the vout of the micro mimimosd, and the vout is going to the screen (left side of the pcb that is not connected to the rx5808).

description.text:
Super simple connector for hot wheels track. It has the pegs for the little holes. We just flip it around if the pieces don't have the holes.

Just made it so I can build some pieces off of it. Suggestions welcome, there's not nearly enough hot wheels content on here!

It's a 20 minute print with ABS. Currently using 20% infill, it doesn't really matter as the only infill goes into the little pegs. The Base is solid as it's only 1.5mm thick.

title: Geeetech Rostock G2 / G2S LED lighting ring

description.text:
LED lighting ring for the Geeetech Rostock G2 / G2S 3D printer

These parts can be used to add an LED lighting ring to the printer. Cable channels are built into the brackets, and a cosmetic cover is supplied that will conceal the wiring and keep it out of harm's way.

Each lighting ring will require:

  • 3 x LED mounting strips
  • 3 x rail mounts
  • 3 x corner covers

The parts are designed to be a tight fit, enabling them to all snap together.

In the photos I used 12v lighting strips which were "daisy-chain" connected around the ring, and then connected directly to a spare set of 12v outputs on the 3D printer's power supply.

Printer:

Geeetech

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Nothing except some basic tidying up with a knife should be required.

Be careful to push the clips onto the rails squarely and carefully. They're designed to be a tight fit, and so pushing them on at an angle may result in breaking one side of the clip.
Designed in Sketchup.

author: qbranchrg

description.text: Spindle light for Bridgeport milling machine with J-head. It uses one of those cheap 120mm led-rings from ebay or banggood. It's quite tight fit to led ring, so I just pressed the ring in and secured it with few drops of superglue. Three M3 screws holds it on milling machines head.

Replacement fan for MABUCHI MOTOR 6V-20V RS-775WC-8514. Mine broke inside Ryobi 18v Circular Saw.
Just print it, no support needed (there is some bridging - but quite easy).
You should use ABS or at least PETG for temperature resilience. I've tested with PLA and it broke/melted down fast.

If you use ABS - do some vapore smoothing.

This is V2 release:

  • fixed stl (there where some separated shells)
  • extended fins by 1mm
  • some additional chamfering

A skeleton case for the Activeon CX Gold action camera. There are 3 pieces. The back slides onto the main housing. The lens tube fits inside the main housing and is optional. I used a 1" diameter rubber furniture leg cap plug as a lens cover.

title: Wanhao/Maker Select v2 Generic Webcam mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: I had to reprint the part of this print that bolts to the carriage, the one I had previously printed warped, which is odd because I printed several rolls of filament before there were any problems (you might want to print Webcam_2 in petg rather than pla just in case). I orignally printed the model by Douglas_K (listed in remixes), but it didn't fit so I remixed it.

This is a mount for a generic webcam that I'm sure many of us have lying around. I posted a picture of the specific webcam so you have an idea of what I'm talking about.

The remixed version has a sphyrical hole in the mount that allows the webcam to be popped in, it fits snugly but you can move it to adjust it as needed.

There are two versions of the part of the model that holds the webcam (which can be switched without removing the bed), a short one and a long one. The long one is v2.

Installation:

Print both models. Webcam (2) is mounted on the plate below the heated bed, the exact same as dumbcomputers - that is, remove the heated bed and install it underneath. It's worth noting that the updated plate has a raised lip all through that area for stability, which I didn't notice before I printed this. You can torque the printed part down so it fits (or at least that's what I did). Feel free to remix this to put grooves in the file if you prefer.

Screw the second piece on with some m4 screws,

Pop the webcam into the hole; as I said, it should fit snugly.

author: scrid2000

description.text:
I created this so that I didn't have to sacrifice my fan for my BLTouch Mount. Here you can have both.

The base mount is just high enough to get the BLTouch in there and then added spacers if needed for more Depth.

The base has been thinned to reduce any Fan blockage.
Holes are set for tapping 3mm screws directly in or you can drill them out for through holes.

I've included the Solidworks File for Customization. Just adjust the 1st Extrusion depth for the overall body length and the 3rd Extrusion to modify the BLTouch depth. The hole for the BLTouch will automatically be created.

Included is one 40mm Body and the bare minimum 14mm for clearance.
The cable pass through is on one end along the top.

title: AR Drone 2.0 Camera Swivel Mount Mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is similar to the one sold online, only plastic and printed from your bot. Allows easy modification of your AR Drone 2.0 forward-facing camera, to allow viewing angles from 90 straight up, to 90 straight down. Overenginerred design includes ~22 degree snap-to angles and ribbon cable guide.

Printed at a sigle shell is best, due to detail of design. A good, precise printer is required. You may want to slow down your bot to make sure it prints well. Adds only 0.2g to your drone.  
Find a bolt and nut that will fit in the hole. For best results make sure the bolt fills the entire hole by adding a shim, drinking straw, or shrink-tube to the bolt. The included printed bold is intended for testing purposes only, and not for use in flight.  
You can tuck the camera's ribbon cable down through the hinge for protection, though you may need to cut a bit more off of the front of your drone to do this.  
Watch the guide on youtube for information about doing this camera mod. Do your homework! Dont screw up your drone because of me.  
Use care when cutting feet off finished print.

description.text:
A spiral wineglass holder for your kitchen or dinner table.

Print 6 of the wineglass arms and snap them together, rotated at 60 degree intervals. There are long marker lines every 60 degrees on the outside of the tube to help get the orientation right. If you wish to try different rotations, there are also short tics at 45 degree increments. If your glasses are heavy you may wish to hot-glue the arm segments together to make the stack more rigid.

The pedestal snaps into the base and the arm assembly snaps into the pedestal. The pedestal is sized so that you can store a wine bottle inside. If desired, you can top off the assembly with something interesting by hot-gluing it to one of the optional top-mount pieces. I've used both chrome cheese platters and musical Christmas snowman globes, but the possibilities are endless.

I have also tried multi-height stack assemblies holding 12 or even 18 glasses spiraling up through two or 3 rotations. The tall stacks look pretty cool and can store multiple wine bottles, but might be better on a low side table or the floor rather than a dinner table. You can also get an interesting effect by printing the glass-holder arms in different colors. I have done alternating red and green for Christmas, but for patriotic days you could try red-white-blue (or French tricolors, etc per your nationality). Orange and black would be good for fall parties.
Mount for the Pi S.USV basic 300 mAh LiPo.

description.text:
ESP-02 uses the same 2.54mm pitch, but has 7 per sides.
ESP-03 and ESP-07 use a 2.0mm pitch with 8 pins per side.
All these modules have different width.
For ESP-12 or ESP-14 modules please use DipClipESP8266_07.stl, they have the same footprint as the ESP-07 module (when ignoring the third side of pins, which is not needed for programming.

Printing with PLA

I've lengthened the handle behind the spring somewhat, and made the spring thinner, to ease the use of the clamp.
For the 2mm pitch versions I use an arm width of 8xew instead of 6xew for better strength.

Printing with PET

When bending, PET has a much wider range for elastic deformation than PLA. PLA often breaks where PET would still do plastic deformation. As PET is also softer in material, we make the pivot spring stiffer with a $pivm multiplier of 1.5 or even 2.0.

Generating multiple variants

We use a Makefile to produce multiple STL files from a single parametric SCAD file. All modules in dipclip.scad that have a comment // AUTO_MAKE_STL are generated as top level modules in separate STL files. The Makefile also demonstrates how openSCAD allows $ special variables to be passed into modules, without being declared parameters to the module. This is used to offer a choice of OPTS for ABS, PLA, PET affecting $pivm.

Regenerate all includede STL files with make clean; make

A well known wooden toy from the past, transferred to 3D printing.
https://youtu.be/Qg6l3KN_7GM
http://www.instructables.com/id/Wooden-Toy-Snake/
Print the body 45 degrees rotated around the z-axis, to fit on the bed. If necessary, scale it down. The end disks of the body have half the thickness of the other disks, so more body elements can be glued together. Prints well in PLA without support. The body has zero infill but be prepared for a long print session. Tail and head are printed with the flat side down. For these two parts a low infill (10-20%) is O.K.
In case you want to play around with it, the OpenSCAD files are included. If you can design a more realistic head, please upload it. I am a simple engineer, not an artist.
If two disks break apart, sand the surfaces and bond them together. There will still be a lot of flexibility left.

author: mathgrrl

title: Mini Atari ST 520 with Arduino, Display and Temperature

description.text:
This is a remix of the beautiful Atari 520ST created by RabbitEngineering. This version features a graphical display and a temperature sensor, and is controlled by an Arduino Nano. The cool way of powering it on is via pushing the num keys on the keyboard and the cool way of powering it off is that it does this itself.

To make the display fit into the monitor, the model was scaled to +15%. The remixed parts of this project include space for the display in the monitor, for the pushbutton below the keyboard and for the temperature sensor below the mouse. This project also adds a desk to nicely place all parts.

Features of this project:

  • Turn on the display by pressing the keyboard
  • See whatever you program on the display
  • Sample contains an Atari image and a temperature display
  • The temperature sensor is optional, and you may add multiple temperature sensors
  • The model can be extended by adding additional sensors and actors

See the contained HowTo for instructions on building and assembling everything.

The temperature sensor is optional. If you leave it away, the program will show no temperatures. On the other hand, you can also add multiple temperature sensors, then the program will show their temperature values one after the other. To use multiple of these sensors, connect all of them in parallel. In any case, only one 4,7k resistor is required.

author: PHolzwarth

title: E3D Chimera with Dual E3D Titan Extruder Direct

description.text:
Have you been wanting to upgrade to dual extrusion but run in to the problems of lose of build space, and having to convert to bowden extrusion; well the solution is here with my custom design for the E3D Chimera with Dual Titan extruders. My Design incorporates:

  • Direct extrusion, One extruder is 2mm away from the Inlet and the other is 45mm away form the inlet but has a guide tube for the PTFE tubing to keep it exactly straight.
  • A footprint that is only slightly larger than one for a single E3D V6 HotEnd.
  • Proximity Sensor mount for both 18mm or 12mm.
  • Proximity Sensor offset from extruder one (Nozzle farthest from sensor) is :
    X: 63.50 and Y: 12.00
    Updated 1/20/17 : Added BL Touch Sensor Mount. X offset : 41.28mm Y offset : 9.65mm
    Updated 1/29/17 : Added Layer Fan, it mounts to the screws on the Titan extruder
    Please dont hesitate to print it out and give it a try and if you have any questions or just need help with assembly feel free to ask.
  • I have also included SLDPRT files for anyone that wants to get measurements or make any personal changes.

**This is a highly intricate mount x-cariage assembly, so please if you have any questions during assembly feel free to ask and I will also post an assembly animation that show the steps.

EVERYTHING IS A TIGHT FIT AND THEREFORE MUST BE ASSEMBLED IN THE EXACT STEPS IN THE ANIMATION OR IT WILL NOT GO TOGETHER PROPERLY.

title: Revised Fully Printable Eggbot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a fully printable eggbot, which was inspired by the original Eggbot as well as the other designs by Zaggo and Berserker. I designed this one to be complete, and fully printable. And easily assembled. Also all parts are no larger than 100mm in any direction so should be printable on any 3D Printer out there. Lastly I wanted to keep the amount of plastic used to a minimum where possible. It's intended to be printed in PLA on my Ultimaker. It's unfinished in that I haven't printed it myself to test it. Normally I don't release things until they are "done" but since Easter is coming up fast, I thought I better get this one out there so hopefully some others can build one in time. I'm hoping to make mine this weekend, and will post pics once it's assembled. It's intended to be used with the spherebot electronics and firmware. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7656 Hope you enjoy! EDIT April 2 2012:
I've refined some of the parts. Updated STLs are uploaded. The Egg cup parts didn't work out as planned, replaced them with suction cup based ones. Also I strengthened and thickened up the Back Plate part as it was a little flimsy (still works in it's original form, as I left it on mine, but I figured it could use some strengthening for general use). EDIT April 4 2012:
Ok another minor revision to a few parts. I've uploaded the new designs now. Also here are some pics of the finished build. I'm still just wrapping up the electronics. The changes I made were shortening the egg cup holders to allow for a larger egg to fit, and I had to adjust the arm pivot to allow the motor shaft to protrude through it. You will need washers on those screws now but it will allow a better depth adjustment for the pen to allow it to center up nicely on the egg (keeping the image from skewing when you print it). EDIT April 4 2012:
Sketchup Sources uploaded. EDIT March 21 2016
I know it's been a long time, and this design is apparently still popular, so I'm planning on doing a full refresh of this design. I'll be posting it sometime in the near future. I'll be completely overhauling it for better stability, printability, and I intend to make it fully Parametric for easier tuning/customization. Also quick shameless plug, anyone looking for anything to be printed, please check out my 3D Hub at: https://www.3dhubs.com/ottawa/hubs/glasswalker
Thanks!

These are rough instructions since I have yet to build it myself, these will be updated once I've verified the build: You will need:
2x NEMA17 Stepper motors
1x 9g hobby servo (Turnigy TG9e or HXT900 is what it was designed for)
All electronics for Spherebot (see link above)
2x 608ZZ "Skate Bearings"
Some M8 Threaded Rod
Several M8 Nuts
Several M4 screws and nuts
A few M4 washers
Some childrens suction darts (see photo, like nerf darts)
A spring (8mm internal diameter, and as long as you need for your frame size)
A Sharpie (fine tip)
An egg or small ball to draw on Printed parts:
1x Back plate
2x End plates
1x Egg cup drive
1x Egg cup idle
1x Idler knob (optional to cover sharp ends of rod if kids will use)
2x Idler Bearing Plate
1x Pen Arm Shaft Coupler
1x Pen Arm Pivot
1x Pen Arm Top Assembly:
  • Put 2 threaded rods through the back plate and tighten it down with nuts so it's in the center.
  • Assemble the two end plates using threaded rods through the 2 bottom, and the rear top hole (the motor mounts face the "front" side) So that the rear plate is between the 2 back plates. The completely flat side of the rear plate should face forward (with the "bumpy side" facing the rear of the machine)
  • bolt the motors onto the NEMA17 mount on one end plate (doesn't matter which) and the rear plate.
  • Press fit the egg drive cup onto the end motor
  • Press fit the arm shaft coupler onto the rear motor
  • Use an M4 nut and short screw to lock the shaft coupler onto the rear motor (the egg cup is just friction fit)
  • Fit 2 M4 nuts into the trapped nut slots on the shaft coupler, and then use line up the arm pivot and put 2 M4 screws through the slots into the trapped nuts (just loose for now you can adjust later)
  • Use an M4 screw, a couple washers in the middle, and a nut to create the hinge between the arm pivot and arm top parts. Tighten only minimally to allow free swinging with no resistance (use nylock nut or locktite to keep it from falling off)
  • drop an M4 nut into the arm top trapped nut hole near the end, and thread an M4 screw into it via the setscrew hole, this is for tightening onto the pen
  • Install the servo in the provided bracket on the arm pivot, so that the servo horn is inline with the arm top and can push it up and down with a little rotation.
  • press fit 2 608 bearings into the bearing plates (these should be tight, so you may need a little tape depending on your printed parts)
  • use 4x (or even 2x) M4 screws to screw the bearing plates in place of the second end plate's NEMA17 motor mount (make sure it's centered)
  • Feed a length of M8 rod through the bearings. it just sits loose
  • Thread (just twist the plastic part on the hole is just a little too small so it should thread onto the rod with some moderate force) the egg cup idler onto one end of the idler rod
  • Fit the spring between the idler cup and the bearing block. It should provide minimal force against the drive cup when empty, and should have enough strength to hold the egg without breaking it.
  • Screw the idler knob on the other end of the idler rod.
  • Attach the rubber suction cup portion on the end of the egg cup parts
  • Fit a sharpie, and wire up the electronics and you should be good to go!

comments.text: Yeah it's the slicer not compensating for extrusion width. A common problem with 3D Printing. Skeinforge supports a feature I think it's called Widen which compensates for hole size and such. I personally use KISSlicer which does a fantastic job. When I design a hole at 3mm it prints 3mm. (so to answer your question yes I design the holes to the exact spec. The trapped nut holes are designed to have clearance for the nut, but only about half a mm or so)

description.text:
This is a car holder/stand for Samsung A3 mobile phones. There are free spaces that are correctly positionned to let access to all the connectors and functions of the model.

The clip has been designed to match the air vents of my car.
Always check the clip compatibility with your car before assembling it to the stand. Modify the design/dimensions if necessary.
I recommend that you change and make the clip robust enough to support the stand with your phone, depending on how you position it in your own car, in order to avoid any risk of breaks and falls. I cannot guarantee the robustness of this thing as you make it yourself, with your own material, your own printer and your own settings. Also use a correct glue in order that the clip and the stand cannot be separated during use.

If you have any doubt about all this, please modify the design accordingly or discard.

I can finally not be responsible for the use that you can make of it in your own car and its consequences. In any case, I strongly recommend to position and use it in a way it cannot disturb you while driving. Always give the priority to your driving action and respect the law! :)

This was my first larger project. I always was annoyed by the loose cable Plug It adapter (491144) which is shown in the last picture. Now it's fixed to the machine and there is not the risk of hitting it with the belt during sanding. Pretty pleased with the result.
In addition a Festool replacement part e.g. # 491716 is required. This fits in the printed thing.

Kodama Trinus

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Support details are in the pictures.
I used Pango 2.3.0.

Some minor manual rework with a cutter was required on my first print.

I did put both parts in one file. That made it easy to print and share support structures. I could just break it into two pieces after printing.

The insert with the cables needs to be bought in addition.

There are different versions of this connector. I found # 491716 to have quite long wires.
I think # 497247 will work as well.

This is a 3D-printable robot for Arduino Mega/Uno/Due Controller Board. There is enough room to stack up to 2x shields on top of the controller board and also mounting holes for ESP8266 WiFI Development Board.

CAD-files, sample code and Android app can be found here: https://github.com/Velli20/ArduinoRobotTank

The tank links used in this project http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52552

  • Front_cover_for_HC_SR04.stl (2 pcs)

Optional:

  • Chassis_fastener_holder.stl (29 pcs). These are for holding chassis nuts in place so it is easier to assemble the robot.

title: Replacement air filter of roomba 760 of IRobot

description.text:
This is a project to manufacture filters compatible with IRobot roomba 760 cleaning robots. The main advantage of this filter is its low cost and can be easily cleaned and reused.
The filter consists of 4 printed pieces that are printed from three stl;
Filter01bot.stl, generates Filter01bot.gcode without settings
Filtro01in.stl, generates Filtro01in80.gcode and Filtro01in90.gcode without solid top and bottom layers and with hexagonal filling of 80%
Filtro01up.stl, generates Filtro01up30.gcode without solid top and bottom layers and with hexagonal filling of 30%
To improve the filtration, between Filtro01in80.gcode and Filtro01in90.gcode we place a layer of kitchen paper, which we tailor to the other pieces.
Using Simplyfy3D, the elimination of the top and bottom solid layers is achieved in the Layer tab and the adjustment of setting the 80% hex filling in the Infill tab

description.text:
Hi!

What's this?

This is a hand cranked drawing machine inspired on some Spiro-drawing machines i've seen recently.

Didn't found anything fully printable so i decided to make my own version.

Why i love this machine?

100% printable!. Except for markers and paper sheets :)
Hand cranked! But may be easy to plug some kind of DC motor.
NO supports at all. I hate supports
Fun and addictive. Those gears, loops and mechanics are highly addictive (at least for me)
Surprises inside. Explore with gears, combinations and you'll find some suprising patterns. Or found ugly and messy drawings :P

What i'm downloading?

ZIP file with all the STL's Many STL files so uploaded as a ZIP with files organized in folders.
PDF assembly guide. Step by step assembly process with pictures and some tips. Please read before asking on comments.
The STL's shown are in ZIP file, just needed to attach some STL files to publish this thing ;)

Hope you enjoy printing, assembling an drawing this one!!
Have fun!!

Advice: Please tell me in comments if there's any file missing or can't print something. After renaming and organizing the STL's i'm affraid i'm forgotting something.(Hope no, but Murphy's always with us)


Customizer for gears and plates: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2052529

To do: (eventually)

  • Assembling and testing video
  • Cleaning and publishing OpenSCAD files
  • Maybe a sort of circular cutter for the paper sheets

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

No supports

Resolution: 0.25 for gears, plates, bars and guides. 0.2 for screws, nuts and small parts

Using brim on small parts

Adjust Horizontal expansion to -0.1 on gears and plates to get a smoother engage

Easy to print, reduce flow and/or use horizontal expansion reduction for pins, gears, and maybe scrrews and nuts if you have trouble inserting or screwing parts

Notes:

Designed to print without support. Use a higher infill to increase durability.

This remix makes it possible to print the rover model with a small printer and it adjusts for some problems in the original NASA model that makes it very hard to print. The remix also adds the option of printing different parts with different colors, since the parts are now separated.

I used my own software to separate the original NASA model into its individual disconnected parts, and got 24 parts if you include the supports and some tiny pieces that didn't seem to be significant. In this remix, duplicate wheels are omitted, but see the discussion below on printing the wheels)

Another reason for separating the parts is to be able to print them in different colors. A third reason is to reduce the risk of complete ruin of everything if one piece fails.

I found that the underside of the main rover body was originally designed with a thin rectangular void on the underside, which essentially made it unprintable. So I filled it in and it was then possible to print without problems. This modification is not visible in the finished model. I also increased the height of the supports where the wheel assembly connects. The support still breaks off easily.

The wheels were a problem, because they were designed with very small footprints, and thus very likely to fail during print by losing adherence. After 3 unsuccessful print attempts, I modified the wheel spokes to extend all the way down to the print bed in order to increase the footprint and adherence. Now the print of the modified wheel was successful on first try. This modification is on the inside of the wheels and not visible in the assembled rover model. Both the original and the modified "easy" wheels are included in this remix, I recommend to print the easy one. Print 6 wheels together at once by instructing the slicer to slice multiple copies of the one you prefer.

The small UHF part is not from NASA, it is my own tiny bonus contribution to make the UHF antenna stand out like in some of the pictures of the rover.

I printed the model using 0.2mm layers and 0.2mm extrusion width.

I did this on TinkerCAD for fun. It's not screen accurate, but it's as close as I can get without driving myself crazy. I haven't printed it yet, but I will add a picture when I do. author: lordarchiebald

title: Modular X-carriage for M150, Wanhao I3 and similar printers

description.text:
Modular X-Carriage for M150 (and similar i3 clones like wanhao duplicator i3)

NOTE: This is useful only if you are actually using different tools often and planning to change between them on a single printer (for e.g. I switch often between single MK10 and dual flex3drive and I'm probably getting one zesty, I use a pen, a laser and proxxon flexy shaft)! If you run only one tool don't waste your time with this holder

WORK IN PROGRESS

  • only few modules available, more to come
  • no clue if this will work at all or be useful at all but it's a fun experiment :D

The idea is to have a single X-carriage snapping on the bearings (RJMP-01-08 IGIS DRYLING are the ones I'm using for the measurements but most of 8mm bearings are identical in size) that holds the cable chain and X limit switch with a "quick release" port in front where you can easily connect / disconnect your extruder, lazor thingy, 3d scanner touch probe etc etc ..

I'm using here M4x5x5 brass inserts to fasten things together as they shown great potential so far.

update 20170129: seems to be working nicely, can be printed without support, break off the "hole guards" after printing and make sure you have properly calibrated printer able to bridge :D ... if you can't bridge or just love printing abs hot so bridging is not very possible you can use support, the "look" of the supported part is not too important anyhow as it's not visible

on the base plate on both sides are the diamond attach sockets - "utility plugs" - for easily attaching peripherals like fans for e.g.

above the T slot for "tool mounting" there's a "tongue slot" for the possible quick release tongue tool part can have

I'm using s3d to slice it with first 9mm (base plate) using 40% infill and full honeycomb structure printing 0.25mm layer height, this gives for a sturdy but very light base plate printed super fast, rest of the print is 70% infill rectilinear so that the bearing "grabber" have enough strength to properly grab the bearing. top part is also printer 0.1mm layer for better precision of the grabbers. I'm also printing the top part few degrees hotter for more strength / better layer adhesion.

if you can't have different stages of the part printed with different parameters, printing a whole part 50% infill with 4 perimeters, 4top+4bottom solid layers and 0.15mm layer will work perfectly for the part, having them printed with different settings just makes it print lot faster

I am using ABS to print this just because I mostly print ABS but the x-carriage and the sliding block can be printed out of anything, PLA will work, PETG will work, HIPS will probably work .. Nylon.. there's not any serious stress nor heat acting on this part so there's no serious limit wrt material, so print with what you feel most comfortable printing :D .. ideally HDPE would be best but it's a tough one to print with

Update 20170131 The first "module" works flawlessly! It's a simple indicator holder. Also tested the "utility plugs" between two backplates, they mesh great and are very strong so this will be a good place to hook utilities (fans, blowers..)

Update 20170201 Added "toolholder BASE" part - this is a base of a toolholder, it does not hold anything, it's just a basic stl on top of which any other toolholder can be based

Update 20170202 Added "toolholder MK10" part - this is a toolholder for MK10 extruder (cold+hot end that comes with Malyan M150, Wanhao Duplicator I3 and number of similar printers) .. on the image the MK10 has base plate, handle, cooling block, throat/insulator, nozzle replaced from original to microswiss cnc cut parts and all metal hotend but it works 1/1 with original plastic parts too).

MK10 toolholder could be bit thinner but I decided to make it use original screws from MK10 since finding long M3's is not a simple task so reusing original ones. You should remove the original fan from the MK10 and use the holder instead of the fan, the 2 screws that used to go trough fan into the motor now go trough holder into the motor.

Print 0.25mm or better (this on the pictures is 0.2) and 25-30% infill. I'm using ABS, the PLA should work too since nothing touching the plastic should be hot. Anyhow, did not test PLA so can't be 100% sure. Need support only "from the print plate", rest of the print should be self supported.

Update 20170606

  • Added a holder for Flex3Drive, both 3mm and 1.75mm, extruder. Use the cosel mini extruder from flex3drive and replace the effector plate with my part :)
  • Added X-carriage V2 this version does not "snap on" to bearing. It clamps over them so it's much more solidly connected allowing for much faster printing

Update 20170611

  • Added "cliponholder for diicoler" - this clips to the mount and allows thorped's fan duct to be attached
  • Added modified thorped's fan duct "thorped funduct - longer", the "back" is just lengthened a bit so that there's enough room to mount the fan

Update 20170611

  • Added the "ASSEMBLY" stl file with all parts inside locked in place
  • removed "under development" tag for the part since now I can say this works very good for me for a while, both the MK10 adapter and the Flex3Drive adapter

onshape

designed using onshape, the whole project is open source so feel free to get all the sources, fork the object and make modifications etc etc...

the whole project is available here on onshape

description.text: Use 18mm engine tube and glue into nozzle with casing stop. Cuts are included for the metal engine lock.
This squirrel key chain works great with key rings.

I bought an AGDA Robotic vacuum cleaner which refused to clean my kitchen floor, backing out of the kitchen as fast as it could, terrified it was going to fall off a cliff.

A search of the net revealed two things>

  1. This machine appears to be one of many coming out of a factory in China called Lilin ( http://www.robotvacuumcleaner.cn/ ) and also appears to be the same as the more commonly known brand Roomba.
  2. There are many many complaints of Roomba vacuum cleaners going backwards when they mistake some dark colours as a long drop.

I tried some masking tape over the sensor as suggested by many forums but the sensors on this one require a gap to let the light through. Having found that a piece of bent white card sellotaped in place worked I decided to make this piece of plastic to do the job properly. My house is all on one level so I will eventually glue these in place (once the warranty runs out on the cleaner).

If you have the same problem and the same sensors, try these reflectors but don't blame me if your vacuum cleaner falls down the stairs.

author: mathgrrl

description.text:
This is a set of 8 unit box organizers for Scythe (Stonemaier Games). There is one embossed version for each of the seven factions. There is also one to hold the money (with enough space for the purple 50s and the green 2s). With these boxes you can fit everything in the box comfortably with out any other extra organizers (besides the resource boxes the game came with). You do have to throw out the unit organizers it came with, of course. And also there is still not enough vertical space in the box to hold the art book with the box being able to cleanly close (you can, however, fit the expansion board).

The boxes can be two color printed. I recommend printing two 0.2mm layers in the unit color, then switching to a secondary color. The box will look fine without the color change as well. The pins are sized to hold 1.75mm filament, I recommend using ones that have been snipped from color change pulls (this way one side is slighly deformed and will stick in the pin hole).

These do not support the air expansion as I don't own it and don't know what that would entail.

title: Old School Space Rocket: The Exhaust Cloud Stand

description.text:
Felt like the Old School Space Rocket needed a stand to show it off to best effect... and I needed something to play around with automatic tab generation in sketchup.
Here's the result, dressed up to look like a cartoon exhaust cloud.

Cut from 12"x12" 1/8" stock and follow your instincts to assemble the parts. ;-) Look at the picture here for hints.
Seriously, it should be fairly obvious what goes where.
When you're done and you're ready to place the rocket in position, hold it at 30 degrees from horizontal, with one fin up and the other two to either side. You should be able to place the bottom of the hull on the lowest stop of the stand's sawtooth, and the hull's spine should drop into the slot cut into each tooth.

author: syvwlch

description.text:
Make sure to properly feed your MakerBot else it might get angry. This laser-cuttable feed spool will make the job easier. Updated:
  • Widened the base to make it more tolerant of skew
  • Reduced the inner splines diameter to make it easier to load filament.

You will need: 2 sheets of 6mm ply, 300mm x 450mm (12" x 18")
2 608 skate bearings
2 8mm nuts
2 8mm washers
1 piece of 8mm threaded rod or a bolt about 130mm long. Cut the .svg file out twice. Assemble the stand using wood glue (and a nail gun if you are impatient like me.) When assembling the spool itself, only put glue on one end of the internal splines. Place the other end on to hold things straight while the glue dries (and when using the aforementioned nail gun.) When everything is dry (or at least nailed!) Remove the unglued side. Place your filament over the splines. You may need to loosen up the filament first, don't try jamming it down over the splines. Re-cover with the side and slip it between the supports of the stand (this may be easier to do with everything on it's side.) Slip a washer, bearing and nut onto the threaded rod and run this assembly through the center of the spool. Note that the washer goes between the bearing and the spool. On the other side of the spool install the washer, bearing and nut and tighten down. You may need to pull the tops of the support away from the spool slightly to prevent binding. You may optionally embellish your spool with colored sharpies. You are now ready to feed your MakerBot!

remixed_from.title: Microsoft LifeCam HD-3000 Web camera/webcam mount

description.text:
Some basic files to hard mount a Lifecam HD-3000 on your robot.

Can be used for the camera alone, or add a high power LED on a heatsink. (Details still TBD, but see the notes section.)

Also on Github: https://github.com/Techbrick/Electronics-CAD

Use short screws when mounting - there is no clearance between the Lifecam and the printed wall.

Also, these files will require a fairly well calibrated printer. There are no tolerances built in on the meshing surfaces.

Heatsink:

The current plan is to try a 1" long section of Heatsink USA's 1.813" heatsink for the LED star.
Drill and Tap four #8-32 screw holes, centered on the corners of a 23/16" x 1/2" rectangle, on the face of the heatsink.

Secure the LED star to the heatsink with thermal tape.

Mount standard 20mm optics over the LEDs.

Wiring:

Currently planning to use Meanwell Constant Current regulators. Power in will be connected to the PDP, and the enable signal will be tied into a Rio DIO, so that we can control the LEDs being on or off.

(Note: For any high power LED, please make sure you can turn it off if you are not using it. Your teammates, opponents, field staff, and spectators will all appreciate it.)

title: Extruder no push fit connection for NEMA-17 motor with integrated Planetary gearbox

description.text:
This is a small extruder that doesn't require a push fit connection. its designed for NEMA-17 motor with integrated Planetary gearbox and spur gear of an outer diameter of 16mm max.

I was getting fed up with the bowden tube keep popping out of the connector so i designed an extruder that didn't require one.

All that is needed is to screw an M4 nut onto the end, cut off any excess tube by nut, use an M2.5 drill bit to take out some of the material from the tube where the nut is so the filament can easily be fed in, Slot the tube/nut into the extruder and clamp down

You will need the following to attach it to the motor/gearbox
2off M3x8 bolts
3off M3x25 bolts
1off M3x16 bolts
1off M4x20 bolts
6off M3 Washers
1off M5 Washer
1off M3 Nylock nut
1off M5 Nylock Nut
1off Bearing 625ZZ (Diameter=16mm, Hole=5mm, Thickness=5mm)

description.text: Based on jridley's simple and effective design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:168586). This is a plate that attaches to the fan, plus an optional extension to attach it to the printer, with a few customizable options. It can be set for 40mm, 50mm, 60mm, or 80mm fans, and screw hole sizes are customizable. It is possible to choose the position of the mounting tab, the length of the mounting tab, and the angle of the mounting screw. There is also an option for a full plate, or a lighter version that only mounts the fan with two screws. The default .stl provides for a 40mm fan with a centered mount tab, a 20mm extension from the flat end to the center of the cylinder, and #6 mounting screws.

title: 20mm Sphere (Boilie) Roller (fishing bait, slingshot, etc.)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I use 20mm balls for my slingshot ammo. I've made a few of these ball rollers to help me make my own slingshot ammo. So typically I use modeling clay. Roll a log of it a little bit bigger than 20mm in diameter, then put it in perpendicular to this ball roller, then I get 5 perfect little spheres each time.

You will need to print two of these and match them together.

The English use this exact same type of tool to roll "Boilies" which is basically dough bait for fishing. Using this tool you can get perfect-ish little spheres. So by all means you could use this to roll your own dough bait for fishing.

This can also be used by polymer clay artists to make perfect little sphere beads.

If there is interest, I may make this into a customizer so that you can designate the sphere size, number of tubes, and have it automagically generate a sphere roller for you.

I designed this in TinkerCAD. You can find the files here...

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dZa7FfQgC6A-20mm-boilie-roller/editv2?sharecode=icTk2Qe4YZ4TcqQy5-0XbloXSCgThniMcX7tC9kDZX4=

title: Eagle PCB - HPGL to Gcode Converter - Powershell

description.text:
Output Gcode is good to be used with your 3dPrinter, use your 3dprinter as a pen plotter.
Extruder is excluded from gcode.

Generate your HPGL-code from Eagle PCB and convert it to Gcode with this PowerShell script.

[Update] - To disable circle ("AA") translation to gcode set - "-GenerateCircles" to "No"

In Eagle PCB: Open your board layout and choose, File->CAM Processor->Output "HPGL"

Usage:
Load script

  1. Save the script to "C:\temp\Convert-HpglToGcode.ps1"
  2. Open powershell and navigate to "C:\temp" (cd C:\temp)
  3. Paste the following in the powershell window ". .\Convert-HpglToGcode.ps1"

  4. Run the command below
    eg. 'Convert-HpglToGcode -Source "C:\Temp\InputFile.hpgl" -Destination "C:\Temp\OutputFile.gcode"'
    Minimum req:
    Convert-HpglToGcode -Source "C:\Temp\InputFile.hpgl" -Destination "C:\Temp\OutputFile.gcode"

    Optional switches:

    HPGL units per mm, default is 40.2

    -HpglUnitsPerMM "40.2"

    Set printer/cnc speed

    -Speed "500"

    home all axis

    -HomeAxis "X Y Z"

    Retention / Lift Z between movement

    -Retention "1.5"

    Generate Circles - HPGL "AA"

    -GenerateCircles N/No/HellNo!

description.text:
A simple filament-supporting frame for a Prusa Mendel (v2) 3D printer. This can be attached to the two parallel threaded rods that form the top of the Prusa's frame.  
The spindle hub models have a small cavity where a 608ZZ bearing can be inserted.

• 2x partial_spindle_lock_with_slot
  • 4x spindle_M8_coupler
  • 2x spindle_hub (or spindle_hub_tall)
  • 4x spindle_rod_idler
  • M8 or 5/16" threaded rod
Simple phone stand made to hold a phone or small tablet. There are two models, one with holes for a charger and one without. I've only printed the one with holes but both should work the same.

Replacement parts for the Ryobi BS902 Band Saw are no-longer available. Unfortunately, as you can see in the third photo, the casting for the blade guides are not very durable. They feel like some sort of pot-metal, maybe the BS in the part number stands for something other than Band Saw...

I glued the parts back together, but didn't trust them to stand up to vibration, so instead I 3d printed a replacement.

This is only a hobby-duty saw, so I think the plastic is probably good enough for a replacement. If I used this daily for work I would probably send it off to be printed in metal.

Thread screw holes

Use an M5 tap to thread the screw holes.

description.text:
The Seed is an answer to a question I asked myself - "What a 3 sided twisty puzzle will look like?" This is a shape made from 3 cylindrical surfaces. You can see it working here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MeHJXTInpKk

You need to print 1 core, 3 edges, 3 centers, 3 caps.
In version 2 I didn't fillet the visible edges to keep it pure in form as this is more of an art object then a puzzle.
I can provide sticker patterns if you message me.

This project is something I've wanted to do for a while, a 3D hypsographic/topographic representation of the Charleston South Carolina peninsula and harbor. The end goal is to laser cut this and mount it in a shadowbox frame on the wall of my home here in Charleston.

The files provided are intended to be first laser engraved then cut with the laser. The SVG file provided will most likely not be formatted for cutting or engraving, please use files provided in the ZIP archive.

This is the result of a ton of work on the backend: I downloaded and processed raw elevation and bathymetry data in ArcGIS, generating and refining contours to represent the intervals to be cut out of 1/8" birch plywood.

I was able to export from ArcGIS into XPS which can be read by Full Spectrum's RetinaEngrave software.

The images were produced in SketchUp, using exported TIFs and DXF data from ArcGIS, stacked to represent the finished physical model.

Very cool idea !!
I also work with GIS (ArcGIS) I tried to make a model with a TIN, but my computer bugged to export in ArScene. Can you explain in more detail how you did to export the elevation and then slice?

comments.author: DMaragna

comments.text: I didn't use a TIN.  I used DEM raster data to interpolate contours as separate layers. I exported each contour layer as a vector line drawing that I then imported into SketchUp to display the 3D rendering. The laser cutter uses the vector line drawings to cut each elevation layer.

description.text:
This is a hanger I designed to allow me to spray paint model car bodies without laying them down. This allows me to suspend the car in the air via the roof, high enough to get coverage on overhangs, and keeps it stable while I paint. Strong enough to hold a 1/24 scale die cast Fiat 500 body with no issues, however plastic bodies or smaller vehicles may require the hanger to be taped down in order to prevent the spray paint pressure from blowing it over.

Any tips or comments are appreciated!

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Honestly, any resolution should work, this object doesn't need to be detailed, so as low detail as possible without delamination of layers is best.

Assembly

Assembly should be relatively straightforward from looking at the finished product.

I recommend lightly sanding all mating surfaces that will be glued as it tend to form a much better bond with PLA and PVA glue.

  • Glue together the half-shafts to form the strut pieces, 5 in total.
    • There will be 2 struts with 1 hole in them for the top and bottom.
    • And 3 struts with holes on both sides for the center.
  • Then Glue the bottom Strut to the bottom piece.
  • Glue a peg into the top of the strut and then glue then next middle strut to it.
  • Repeat with the 2 other middle struts, finishing with the top strut.
  • Then glue the top piece on.

These instructions sounds terrible to me, but it's hard to explain without showing.

If anybody has any trouble understanding the instructions, please comment and I will gladly improve them. Just trying to get this up quick in case somebody really needs this sort of thing.

HAPPY PRINTING!

Oh, and HAPPY PAINTING!

description.text:
I was about to print some replacement skids for my snowblower. Then, I realized that I only use my snowblower on my concrete driveway and sidewalks. So I didn't really need skids. I had seen a couple people weld on casters in place of skids, but I thought I could do this with 3D printed wheels instead.

These wheels require 2x standard 608Z skateboard bearings per wheel (4x bearings total). I used the original bolt, added a nut, then the wheel, then the lock nut. Make sure you print these with 5-6 shells so that they won't wear out as quickly.

After I installed these, it is super easy to move the snowblower around. They work great!

These wheels are the same diameter as standard skids (https://www.amazon.com/Arnold-Universal-Deluxe-Two-Stage-Throwers/dp/B002MRM6KQ), but I included the .stp file if you need to change them for your specific snowblower. For me, they provide a 2-3mm gap between the concrete and the scraper plate.

UPDATE:
I split the wheel in half so that bearings are on both sides of the central separator. This prevents the wheels from moving laterally. You will need to print 2 copies of each v2 wheel half along with the bearing spacer.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hHQxRiuszwY

title: Green Day Heart Hand Grenade Sign

description.text:
Updated: 8/14/2017 -- Added HeartGrenade-Black.stl, HeartGrenade-Red.stl, HeartGrenade-White.stl for multi-extrusion machines, like the Prusa i3 MK2 with MMU. You can print the original SIGN-GD.stl, and change filament at the appropriate layer heights or you can slice with these three STLs to print all colors using multiple extrusion.

All credit for this goes to to the original artist -- I simply traced the image and extruded and printed it in three different filaments. I'm not even sure it is OK to upload something like this but I thought other fans would enjoy printing one so I'm going to leave it here until/unless the band or their agents request it be removed. I've seen similar things for other bands uploaded so I hope that means it is ok or at least usually not something bands/labels get upset about.

I changed filaments twice (using a single extruder), base layers (for the background) was done in black, the next set of layers for the hand and the pin are in white and finally red for the grenade. I hope everyone enjoys.

I also included little stands for the sign to sit in -- the tolerance is such that it has a slight angle when sitting on a surface in these stands. You obviously need to print two of the stands.

title: Prusa i3 mk2 extruder cover w/ extra clearance

description.text:
EDIT: I installed the hotend incorrectly, it needs to be rotated 90 degrees. I'll give that a try and see if it still has an issue; if it does I'll update this to add more clearance but not as much and if not then I'll leave this without the part as a warning to future generations =]

This is still an option if you need extra clearance, but you probably don't need it.

The extruder cover that prusa ships has an unfortunate issue where the hotend is actually less than 2mm away from the nearest printed part; I've had this soften and warp the plastic a few times when doing long prints at high temperatures, but even worse I find that when you install the e3d silicone sock (which would have prevented major problems for me a couple different times) the sock actually touches / is wedged into the plastic. Since silicone is a good conductor this results in the plastic always melting and your cooling fan mount gets ruined -- along with whatever you're printing and the sock.

This is an attempt to increase the clearance between the hotend and the printed parts; it does mean that the cooling fan isn't as close but I think it will still work adequately well.

Notes:

Print with the same settings you'd normally print the extruder cover part with. (I use .25mm height and 85% infill, but then I am also printing with high temp ABS w/ carbon fiber, so maybe that's overkill).

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text: This is a Mod I designed for a PlayStation 3 controller. This mod reroutes the square, triangle, circle and X keys so that you can keep your right thumb always on the joystick. I tried to make the parts as simple as possible for ease of assembly and printing. To completely assemble the controller mod you will need five 6-32 bolts and five 6-32 lock nuts. I got 1.5 inch long bolts and cut them to the right size.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

25%

I made all the holes for the bolts nice and snug to reduce slop and wobble around the bolts and to give a nice playing experience. Since the holes are snug, some needed a little sanding to allow the bolt to slide through. So I used a small round file to open up the bolt holes a little. Assembly Step 1

Glue the base and main body parts together as shown

Step 2

Glue the Square Button, Square Presser, and Square Pad together as shown.

This is easiest done by assembling the square button onto the main body and the putting some super glue in the square button socket and then putting square presser into the socket on the Square button. Then put glue around the top of the square button socket. Hold the square presser arm flat on the main body surface for a few minutes to allow super glue to set.

Then glue the square pad on the end of the arm.

Step 3

Bolt on the triangle lever.

Step 4

Bolt on the O lever.

Step 5

Bolt on x button.

Step 6

Slide the controller mod onto your PS3 controller and put the last bolt through the holes between the joysticks and tighten it snug.

title: MPCNC Universal Mount for Roland Style Drag Knife

description.text:
A simple adaptation of HicWic's Universal Mount 525 to attach a Roland or Liyu style vinyl cutter to AllTed's MPCNC.

There wasn't a really satisfying mount for this style of drag knife that fits the Universal Mount. So, I made a very rudimentary mount. I found that the mounts that are spring loaded actually work against you, since they make corner action's practically impossible. Following Allted's advice, I use a piece of glass under the vinyl to make a nice flat surface (the carbide cutter is adjusted to only cut through the vinyl without scratching the paper backing).

Feel free to let me know if you think this part needs any adjustments. The zip ties seem to keep it plenty tight for my purposes.

Enjoy!

Notes:

1/16/2017 - I marked this thing as a work in progress. Version 1 held the cutting tool too high in Z space. Version 2a fixes the tool height issue, but I have not printed the new part yet. I also added the Sketchup project file in case someone wants to modify the design.

1/18/2017 - I unmarked this thing as a work in progress. It prints great and is functional.

remixed_from.author: lamiskin
remixed_from.title: Keyring - Trust Me I Am An Engineer

title: Trust Me I Am an Engineer keyring

description.text:
TL;DR: This will be an old version very soon, find the current version here once it's been posted. Keyring and Plaque are great too, definitely check them out.

Update: This thing is about to be replaced by a new and improved version! (link to be updated after I publish it) Hooray! That's right folks, I finally got around to my future plans! This time, I re-designed it from scratch in openSCAD, a program that's actually parametric, which was way easier to do than I had expected. I totally should have done that earlier. You're still welcome to print this one out, it is still pretty cool, but the new one has fancy stuff like real gear geometry and computer-generated text and multiple variations and even Customizer (woot woot!), so you should definitely check that one out first! Also, due to the update, this thing is no longer a work in progress! You're welcome to anyone viewing this after 2020.

This was remixed from lamiskin's Keyring - Trust Me I Am An Engineer, which itself is a remix of JoshKonstantinos's Engineer Plaque, both of them are fantastic, and I couldn't have possibly made this without all the work they put into their versions, so you should definitely go check them out before you print this.

I really liked the Keyring version, but it's quite thick, and I like to be conservative with my filament. I scaled it down a bit, but the beveled edges just don't scale well, and that combined with my sub-par slicer to give me a very poor quality print. That's when I decided to remix it.

Here's what I did:

  • I scaled it down to roughly (very roughly) the size of a credit card. It's definitely smaller than a credit card, but it gives you a rough idea.
  • I scaled the height down to 4mm. I've had a lot of luck with this height on other projects, so I thought it would work well here.
  • I removed the back side gears and lettering. I'm sure you put a lot of work into putting it there, lamiskin, but my slicer can't handle oddly shaped bridges, so I had to get rid of it. (I may yet try to make a version like mine, but with both sides)
  • I redesigned the hole. I never liked the not-quite-circular hole in the Keyring design, so I swapped it for a round hole. (It came out a bit smaller than I intended, I may redesign that again)
  • I rounded the edges and corners, including the inside of the hole. Bevels don't work very well at this size unless you have an extremely precise printer. Rounds actually come out pretty bad too, if you want them to be perfect, but I don't. Once again, don't expect it to be a perfectly circular arc; it won't be. It will, however, be rounded just enough that it doesn't feel sharp, and I think it makes it look really nice too.

Here are my future plans for this thing, all of which can be found in the new version! (once I upload it):

  • As I mentioned above, I would like to make another version that restores lamiskin's double-sided-ness. My slicer won't be able to handle it, but that doesn't mean yours can't.
  • Also as I mentioned above, I would like to re-redesign the hole to make it larger and slightly closer to the outside.
  • I would like to completely redo the text. It appears as if JoshKonstantinos's original design used hand-made 3D text, and if I can figure out how to replace that with computer-generated 3D text, then I think it would look even sharper.
  • If you have any suggestions for further modifications, you can still message me here, but keep in mind that they may be in the updated version, so be sure to check it first!.

I have included the .3mf file from 3D Builder, in case anyone wants to tinker with it on their own. Happy printing!

Printer:

daVinci 1.0 Pro

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10%, honeycomb

Notes:

It may seem a bit counter-intuitive, but do not print this with supports. See the fifth bullet under Here's what I did in the summary above for an explanation.

If you plan to use this as an actual key-chain (I don't), you may want to increase the wall thickness and/or the infill percentage, and of course ABS will be more durable than PLA. Mine seems quite sturdy, but it hasn't been abused by everyday use on a keychain.

If you plan to scale this up at all, first I recommend that you check out lamiskin's Keyring - Trust Me I Am An Engineer and JoshKonstantinos's Engineer Plaque, they may do the trick a little better. If you still want to print mine scaled up, you may want to consider using supports, as the edge rounding likely won't print well if it's much larger.

description.text:
Got a 4.3" backup monitor for x-mas for my Runner. While I was attempting to rotate the original back mount with the sticky pad it broke in two. At that point I decided to make my own system. Designed this mount to locate in the cigarette lighter hole. The cigarette lighter needs to be gutted down to the clear and white plastic ring (pic) which holds the metal tube that holds the lighter part...the mount goes in that part. This allows the wires to be fed through the mount and to the behind the dash. The mount has a few parts. The "ring" is a keyed ring that contours the cl recess to lessen the chance of rotation. The "adapter post" mounts inside the screen. This takes place of the factory mount. You'll need to open up the screen and take out the original and put this in it's place. "st" is a mini ring that goes over the outside of the adapter pin and locks that in place to keep from rotating. The mount has a 40* angle up. Although this is for a specific screen...

https://www.amazon.com/Mirror-Foldable-Rearview-Monitor-Screen/dp/B01D9YSSPM/ref=sr_1_1?s=car&ie=UTF8&qid=1481995292&sr=1-1&keywords=backup+camera+monitor&refinements=p_n_feature_keywords_two_browse-bin%3A7014926011

...it may work with others , or at least give you some ideas and a starting point for your mount...

description.text:
Simple spool holder that uses any skate bearing to provide zero drag on the filament. Requires 1 skate bearing ( typical 8mm ID ) and a 8mm or longer m3 bolt.

Print 2 washers and sandwich them between the bearing. Slide the 3d printed bolt through the washers and bearing and press it tight against the filament guide main part. Screw in m3 bolt through the main part to secure the filament bolt in place. Slide on the filament guide pulley and your good to go. I did print the Filament Guide Pulley with supports standing not on its side. Enjoy!

The rose itself will only print upside down.

description.text:
Needed some carpet runner rod holders. Got some carpet rods from Menards which are .25" in diameter. The mounting hardware supplied with the rods would be difficult on my stairway so i designed my own.

I made the holders with Black PLA and mounted them with #4 3/4" brass flat head screws. The file RunnerSupport.stl are the lower mounts while the RunnerSupportUpper.stl is mounted under the top lip. I thought I could use the RunnerSupport.stl for both but found one of the mounting legs stuck out too far.

I made it tight on the carpet with only 1/8" gap for the carpet to fit under. I still used carpet tape to keep the carpet from walking on the treads, (local code requirement) Be sure to drill pilot holes. Brass screws can easily twist off in red oak.

Have fun!

Parts to make an underslung effector. Moving the effector plate down closer to the nozzle reduces the scaling effect of effector tilt. This assembly also uses my Z bend sensor, which eliminates the inaccuracy caused by effector tilt on measuring Z height.

This is how your typical clone hotend looks when it arrives from China.

Disassemble, and drill out the guts with a 4mm (or slightly larger, 11/64" works well) drill bit. This is so that the PTFE tube can slide all the way through.

Then, hack off the bottom 2 fins with a dremel.

You should be left with this:

Clean it with a file so that the fins are completely gone, and you're left with a rounded cylinder.

Spacer

Start with a spare heatbreak, and grind the threads off so that the outside is smooth.

Now cut it off to be about 5mm long.

Grind the end of your good 30mm heatbreak so that it isn't chamfered on the end. Putting it in a drill while on the grinder ensures a flat surface.

Assemble as shown.

Most of the details of the Z height sensor are available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1517363

However note that the STL for this effector is slightly different. For a start, it uses a 2 gram servo, and the mounts are different. So use the STL provided here.

The part that connects the Z height rod to the screw can be fabricobbled out of just about anything. I used a brass screw, with a 2mm hole drilled down through the middle. Then drill a 2.5mm hole across it, and tap a thread with a 3mm tap.

It should go together like this:
Start with an aluminium effector, and countersink the mounting holes so that the countersunk M3 screws sit flush against the surface.

The effector goes together as shown in the pictures below.

You might need some washers to space out the optical endstop so that it triggers reliably on the end of the Z height trigger (bicycle spoke).
